channel.title: Resources on NYU Stats Club
channel.description: Recent content in Resources on NYU Stats Club

item.title: Git tutorial
item.description: Workshop details Time: 9/23 @ 7pm EST Zoom: TBD What you need to do prior to the workshop RSVP here! Install git Set up a GitHub account During the workshop Access the slides here

item.title: Computing resources
item.description: DataCamp Browser-based courses with an inteactive console for learning data science and analytics. If you take Marc’s Statistical Computing class, you’ll get free access. datacamp.com RDocumentation The best web-based source for R libraries and function documentation. rdocumentation.org R-bloggers Blog posts on almost any R-related topic. r-bloggers.com Stack Overflow and StackExcahnge These are self-evident. Just google your computing question and Stack Overflow or StackExchange are bound to be in the top five results.

item.title: Statistical methods resources
item.description: UCLA statistics UCLA maintains pages explaining almost every statstical test and method. It contains examples, code, and interpretations. stats.idre.ucla.edu StatQuest Josh Starmer’s YouTube channel does a great job breaking down major statistical methodologies in a visual format. It’s also commically whimsical. youtube.com/…/StatQuest Richard McElreath’s Bayesian course Want to learn Bayesian methods with intuitive explanations? Richard McElreath’s recordings of his lectures are free on YouTube. youtube.com/…/RichardMcElreath UC Business Analytics R Programming Guide Short, simple explanations of statistical methods and working with R.

item.title: Data sources
item.description: Places to search for additional datasetss kaggle Crowdsourced datasets that are a staple of the data science community. These datasets tend to be cleaner and larger. kaggle Google Dataset Search A dataset search engine from Google. These datasets are well documented via a standard metadata schema. Google Dataset Search NYC OpenData Free, public data from NYC government agencies. Topics range from policing to education to 311 calls. Want to find out how many squirrels are in Central Park or how many people have been tested for Covid-19 in the city?

item.title: Datasets
item.description: Neat and approachable datasets Iris This dataset is the go to dataset for pedagogical use. It’s not particularly interesting but you should become familiar with it as many lessons depend on it. The dataset is preloaded in R > head(iris) Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species 1 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa 2 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa 3 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 4 4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa 5 5.
